title: Aseptic and Alopecic Nodules of Scalp: A Rare and Underdiagnosed Entity
patient: A 26-year-old woman presented with chief complaint of nodular lesions over the scalp for 2 months. Lesions were nonpainful and were associated with hair loss. There was no history of insect bite, trauma, or medical local procedures. Cutaneous examination revealed two alopecic nodules in occipital and frontal areas of scalp. Nodules were nontender, dome-shaped, firm in consistency, size varying from 1.5 to 3 cm and associated with nonscarring alopecia with surrounding normal scalp []. On histopathology, subcutaneous tissue showed chronic lymphoplasmocytic infiltrate and few multinucleated foreign body giant cell [Figures and ]. Specific staining for microorganisms with Periodic acid–Schiff, Giemsa, and Ziehl–Neelsen was negative, as were mycological and bacteriological cultures []. On the basis of clinical and histopathological findings, the diagnosis of AANS was made, and the treatment was started with doxycycline 100 mg twice daily, and after 1 month follow-up, nodular lesions subsided, and there was improvement in hair growth [].
